description: From Chinese Pidgin English chop (“quick”) (compare chop-chop) + stick. The first element is a calque of Chinese 筷子 (kuàizi, “chopstick”), derived from 快 (kuài, “quick”).

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) An East Asian eating utensil usually used as a pair and held in one hand to grip pieces of food or occasionally to mix liquids or scoop up small pieces of food. The utensil is a stick, usually made of wood and measuring approximately 23cm (10 inches) in length.

verbs.description: chopstick (third-person singular simple present chopsticks, present participle chopsticking, simple past and past participle chopsticked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, informal) To pick up (food) using chopsticks.
